tossups.question: A man with this occupation buys Barnegat Books in a Lawrence Block novel about one of these people Who Liked to Quote Kipling. That character, Bernie Rhodenbarr, owns a cat named for another character with this occupation, a cricketer who is accompanied by “Bunny” Manders. That amateur (*) cracksman was created by E. W. Hornung. A cat who specialises in this activity is “a ginger cat, he’s very tall and thin” and is consistently described as “not there!”. That cat described as “Flying Squad's despair” is Macavity. In the Hobbit Thorin and Gandalf employ Bilbo in this role which he accomplishes by breaking into Smaug’s lair. For 10 points, what sort of criminal breaks into a property to steal.

tossups.answer_sanitized: burglar [or thief; accept burglary, stealing, or similar answers]

tossups.question: This people’s San Pedro mummy, found in the 1930s, has sometimes been cited as proof of the existence of a race of tiny people. Patrick Edward Connor led a massacre of members of this tribe who had converted to Mormonism during the American Civil War. A US Supreme Court Case in 1938 between the US government and these people, who live alongside the Arapaho on the Wind River Reservation, found that mineral rights belong to tribal peoples rather than the government. (*) Pompey’s pillar is named for a member of this tribe, Jean-Baptiste Charbonneau, who accompanied his mother on the Lewis and Clark Expedition. For 10 points, Pocatello and Sacajawea were members of what tribe found in Idaho and Wyoming?

(*) Pompey’s pillar is named for a member of this tribe, Jean-Baptiste Charbonneau, who accompanied his mother on the Lewis and Clark Expedition. For 10 points, Pocatello and Sacajawea were members of what tribe found in Idaho and Wyoming?

tossups.question: The ACE (“A-C-E”) and ADE (“A-D-E”) models used to describe these people both contain a term for environmental effects which can be extracted by using discordance, as in the Maudsley bipolar study. Joseph Murray earned half the 1990 Nobel in Medicine for a pioneering procedure on these people, who are typically ten out of ten in HLA types. The correlation for two different varieties of these people are used in Falconer’s formula, which is used to calculate the broad sense heritability of a trait. Iso-grafts like the first successful kidney (*) transplant are defined by occurring between these people, removing the risk of organ rejection because they share a serotype and a blood type. For 10 points, name these very closely related people whose monozygotic examples share their entire genotype.
tossups.answer: identical twins [or monozygotic twins; accept dizygotic, fraternal, or sororal twins; prompt on siblings, brothers, or family members; prompt on organ donors with “what is unique about them?”]

tossups.question: Ludwig Wittgenstein declared that this man was the last composer worth listening to. J.S. Bach’s Nach dir, Herr, verlanget mich ("VUR-lahn-get mick") inspired the theme of a 4th movement passacaglia that this man used to conclude a symphony. Going against the grain, Arnold Schoenberg wrote an essay characterising this composer as a “Progressive”. Along with Albert Dietrich and Robert Schumann, this man composed the collaborated F-A-E Sonata for Joseph (*) Joachim (“yo-ah-KEEM”). The “Choral St. Antoni” inspired a set of Variations on a Theme by Joseph Haydn by this man. This composer’s second symphony is often nicknamed “Beethoven’s Tenth”. tossups.question: Failure to reduce this phenomenon during formation of an aerogel will produce a xerogel (“ZERO-gel") as its network collapses. Joseph Plateau’s work on systems governed by this phenomenon includes the result that a vertical stream is unstable when its wavelength is greater than pi times its diameter. Supercritical fluids do not experience this phenomenon because they lack a key phase boundary. The magnitude of this phenomenon is sometimes expressed using the cgs ("c-g-s") units of dynes per centimeter, equivalent to units of energy over (*) area. When there is zero pressure difference across a surface defined by this phenomenon, every point will be a saddle point, resulting in zero mean curvature and minimal surface area. Bubbles are drawn into spheres because of—for 10 points—what phenomenon, in which cohesive forces pull molecules of a liquid together?

Supercritical fluids do not experience this phenomenon because they lack a key phase boundary. The magnitude of this phenomenon is sometimes expressed using the cgs ("c-g-s") units of dynes per centimeter, equivalent to units of energy over (*) area. tossups.question: A pataki (“pa-ta-KEE”) is a parable about these beings. The human body is analogized to a “horse” that these beings ride in the tradition of trance possession. One of these beings is represented by a sculpture consisting of an egg-shaped concrete head with cowrie shells arranged like a face. An especially-frightening one of these beings wields a double-headed axe, and casts a “thunderstone” on those who offend him; that one of these beings is named (*) Shango. These beings took on human forms as Irunmole (“ee-ROON-mo-lay”) after being sent to Earth from the spirit world by Olodumare (“OH-lo-du-MAH-ray”). For 10 points, name these beings venerated in the Yoruba religion, who also appear in Candomble (“can-DOM-blay”) and Santeria.

For 10 points, name these beings venerated in the Yoruba religion, who also appear in Candomble (“can-DOM-blay”) and Santeria.

tossups.question: This author described being introduced to English by his father’s translations of Dickens and Victor Hugo, as well as his original drama Komedia, in his memoir, A Personal Record. In another novel by this author of (*) Almayer’s Folly, Charles Gould entrusts an Italian to look after his silver on the verge of a revolution in Costaguana. tossups.question: Polyphase motors that operate via this phenomenon may use squirrel-cage rotors. Léon Foucault (“foo-COE”) found that this phenomenon increased the amount of force necessary to rotate a copper disk due to the eddy currents it creates. Tightly-wound solenoids are ideal for exploiting this phenomenon, such as in transformers. bonuses.leadin: This machine’s job is to use a brush to keep a blood-like fluid from spreading. For 10 points each:
answers: People’s Republic of China [or PRC; do not accept or prompt on “Republic of China”]
dogs [or canines or Canis lupus familiaris; accept specific breeds; anti-prompt if you are not sure it an answer given is a kind of dog]
parts: Name this artwork consisting of a mechanical arm fixed to the floor of an exhibit. Despite what users on TikTok say, this machine did not break down in 2019, and its name was not changed to the past tense.
Can’t Help Myself is by Sun Yuan and Peng Yu, whose art often portrays the uncertainty of life in this country, their home.

In 2017, there were calls to boycott the Guggenheim due to Yuan and Yu exhibiting these animals trying to fight each other while tied to treadmills. Giacomo Balla painted the “dynamism” of one of these animals.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about successful E-sports teams.
parts: This Ukrainian team has been highly successful in both CS:GO ("c-s-go") where they have been led by s1mple ("simple") and in DOTA 2 where they won the first International led by Puppey and Dendi.
Edward Gaming won the 2021 League of Legends World Championship which were held in this country. Bobby Fisher received political asylum in this country from 2005.
In 2021, this English football team, the current Premier League champions, started a Fortnite Battle Royale team by signing Threats, having signed Jack Grealish from Aston Villa only months earlier.

bonuses.leadin: According to Dudo, this Viking warlord signed the 911 Treaty of Saint-Clair-sur-Epte (“san-clair sur ept”). For 10 points each:
answers: Charles [accept Charles III, Charles the Simple, Charles the Straightforward, Charles X, or Charles Philippe]
parts: Name this first Duke of Normandy. This ruler was succeeded by his son, Wiliam Longsword, in 928 AD.
Rollo’s first wife was Poppa, who hailed from this French town. The Norman conquest of England was recorded on a tapestry embroidered in this commune.

Rollo received the Norman lands from a “Simple” King of France with this name. The tenth French king of this name was an ultra-royalist leader in the 19th century, and was also derogatorily called “the Simple.”

bonuses.leadin: One can scrape the inner surface of these devices with their fingernail to find europium, which is otherwise mostly useless. For 10 points each:
answers: CRTs [or CRT monitors; or CRT TVs; accept cathode-ray tube monitors or picture tubes; prompt on television sets, television cameras, TVs, electron guns, video camera tubes, or image dissectors]
parts: Name these devices which exploited the persistence and intensity of various rare earth element oxides. The technology underlying these heavy commercial objects was inspired by farmers plowing a field.

Thick CRTs were phased out in favor of thin displays based on liquid crystals, which serve this purpose. One should not remove the outermost panel of an LCD, as it also serves this purpose sometimes performed by 3D glasses.
LCDs have been superseded by TVs based on “organic” examples of these devices. These devices only allow electricity in one direction, producing light as it does.

bonuses.leadin: Stories about this character were created by the Stratemeyer Syndicate and generally published under the name Victor Appleton. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this fictional inventor involved in a number of best-selling children’s novels in the 1910s and 1920s. A sort of punning phrase named for this character originated in a book about this man and his airship.
The name of this rarely-lethal weapon, widely used by police forces since the 1980s, is derived from an acronym for “Tom Swift’s Electric Rifle.”
Tom Swift was partially inspired by this Brazilian inventor, whom Brazilians often cite as the inventor of the airplane for his creation of the 14-bis aircraft.

bonuses.leadin: Maps created by this person used colors ranging from dark blue to gold to code blocks on a spectrum ranging from "vicious and semi-criminal" to "upper classes, wealthy". For 10 points each:
parts: Name this British philanthropist who funded a pioneering life and labour survey in London that was one of the first looks at urban poverty using modern methods.
Booth's life and labour survey was intended to supplement data from this regular population survey. A survey of this type in the United States is constitutionally mandated to occur every 10 years.
Booth's uncle-in-law, Thomas Babington Macaulay, was a leading figure in this approach to history. Broadly, this approach presents a march of progress from the past into the present.

bonuses.leadin: One of these structures on Maud Hughes Road in Ohio is said to scream at night. For 10 points each:
answers: bridges [accept the Screaming Bridge of Maud Hughes Road]
parts: Name these structures. Urban legends across America purport that some of these structures are haunted by babies who fell into the water below them.
Old Alton Bridge in Texas is named for its haunting by a businessman who farmed these animals. A monster said to suck the blood of these animals was first reported in Puerto Rico.
This Scottish bridge in West Dunbartonshire is thought to be haunted due to repeated incidents of dogs apparently becoming agitated and leaping off of it into the River Clyde.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each name these songs featured on the soundtrack to Magic Mike XXL:
parts: Channing Tatum and the other dancers dance to this Ginuwine song which contains the lyrics “My saddle's waiting/Come and jump on it”.
For the film, actor Matt Bomer covered this artist’s track “Untitled (How Does It Feel)” from the acclaimed album Voodoo.
Joe Mangianello dances to the song “I Want It That Way” by this iconic 1990s boy band in an impromptu outdoor routine in Magic Mike XXL.

bonuses.leadin: This procedure has attracted controversy because of mortality rates of around 20% after the collection of amebocytes (“a-ME-ba-cytes”) and release back into the ocean. For 10 points each:
answers: harvesting the blood of horseshoe crabs [accept answers that indicate extracting blood from horseshoe crabs; accept Limulus amebocyte lysate or Tachypleus amebocyte lysate in place of “blood”; accept Limulus polyphemus, Tachypleus gigas, or Tachypleus tridentatus in place of “horseshoe crabs”; prompt on answers giving TAL in place of “blood”; do not accept on “milking”]
parts: Describe this procedure which produces a blue liquid from the joint in one animal’s hinged carapace. This process is necessary to produce LAL, which is essential in testing for bacterial contamination.

In an effort to reduce reliance on horseshoe crabs, Jeak (“jack”) Ling Ding produced the first kit based on a version of limulus factor C with this distinction. Proteins of this sort are created by embedding their gene into a plasmid of another origin, allowing them to be cloned in a laboratory setting.
LAL undergoes this process in the presence of pathogens. The end of this process is mediated by platelets.

bonuses.leadin: Each stanza of a hymn by this author ends with the line “victory, victory, victory to thee!” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author who wrote “thou hast made me endless, such is thy pleasure” in Gitanjali.

The first verse of Tagore’s hymn to “the ruler of the minds of people” was adapted into one of these works. “My Golden Bengal” (“ben-GALL”), another of his poems, was also adapted into one of these works.

India’s national anthem, Jana Gana Mana, is adapted from a hymn Tagore wrote as part of this religious and social movement. This monotheistic movement was founded and developed by Tagore’s father and grandfather.

bonuses.leadin: Rudd Weatherwax and his brother trained their Rough Collie, Pal, to play this character. For 10 points each:
answers: Pugsley Addams [do not accept or prompt on “Addams”]
parts: Name this iconic canine character who frequently saved Timmy, though not usually from a well.
Rudd Weatherwax also trained Spike, a Mastiff-Labrador Retriever crossbreed who played the lead in this 1957 Disney film about a boy who befriends a stray dog in 19th century Texas.
In the 1960s, Rudd’s nephew, Ken Weatherwax, played this brother of Wednesday Addams, who wears a striped shirt.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about how NMR ("N-M-R") is better than other techniques:
parts: Trying to find the structure of a molecule from an IR ("I-R") spectrum will leave one mystified, as it has complicated and overlapping peaks for various motions of this kind. These motions include wagging, rocking, and stretching.

Rotational spectroscopy can struggle to find the geometry of some halogenated compounds because chlorine has two naturally-occurring examples of these things. Neutron count differentiates these things for an element.
By contrast, NMR can determine the specific chemical environment of every atom in terms of chemical shift relative to this molecule, the reference in both carbon and proton NMR.

bonuses.leadin: This book identifies a distinction between "latent" groups and "privileged" groups, where in the latter, some members get disproportionate benefit from the group. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this book by Mancur Olsen which established the study of how groups decide to do things.

One of the most studied collective action problems is this one, where individual users acting in self-interest deplete a common resource. It is often illustrated with an example of farmers letting their sheep graze.

The environmental depletion that occurs in the tragedy of the commons can be thought of as one of these things. A theorem developed by Ronald Coase states that in a market with property rights, these things will be accounted for efficiently.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about German fairy tales:
answers: the Grimm brothers [or the brothers Grimm; accept Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm in either order]
the “Town Musicians of Bremen” [or the “Bremen Town Musicians” or die “Bremer Stadtmusikanten”]
“Seven at One Blow” [accept similar four-word phrases, like “Seven in One Hit”]
parts: These brothers collected German fairy tales in their Children’s and Household Tales.

In this fairy tale, the title animals decide to move into a cottage owned by a pack of robbers after scaring them away. A statue in northern Germany depicts the four animals of this fairy tale standing atop one another.

In the story The Brave Little Tailor, the title character fashions a belt buckle with this four-word phrase to signify his proficiency at killing flies, which a giant misinterprets as his proficiency at killing men.

bonuses.leadin: This dynasty supplanted the Almohads who were decimated after their defeat to Christian forces at Las Navas de Tolosa. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this North African dynasty founded by Abd al Haqq ("abd ull-HAHK") which ruled much of Morocco from the 12 to 14th centuries. This dynasty built the Bou Inania, one of many madrassas.
The Marinid promotion of learning allowed them to briefly patronise this Tunis-born scholar, the author of the Muqaddimah ("moo-KAHD-ee-mah") who is sometimes cited as the father of sociology.
The Marinids and their successors, the Wattasids, both ruled from this Moroccan city, which shares its name with a hat not typically produced in the country.

bonuses.leadin: A version of an isomorphic 6-6 layout was designed by Paul von Janko in 1882. For t01 points each:
answers: upright piano [do not accept or prompt on “grand piano”]
parts: Name this instrument whose shape was changed by famous designers including Johannes Zumpe ("ZUM-pee"). Composer Ignace Pleyel made some improvements to a design for this instrument by Robert Wornum.
Pleyel’s pianos were particularly acclaimed by this Polish composer who would give annual renditions at the Pleyel salon while in Paris.
Chopin and Liszt met at the Pleyel salon and performed together at a charity concert for this composer’s wife Harriet Smithson.

bonuses.leadin: After Li Na, this woman became the third Chinese tennis player to make a major semi-final. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this tennis player, who was likely forced to disappear after accusing an important CCP member of sexual assault.

Peng accused this former Vice Premier of sexual assault. This man has served as the Communist Party Secretary of both Shandong and Tianjin, and he has overseen committees organising major projects such as the Three Gorges Dam and One Belt One Road.
Peng made the accusations on this website, the most popular microblogging service in China.

bonuses.leadin: At the end of this novel, the central character is pregnant in an unnamed town just like the ancestor she has tracked down. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Booker Prize winning novel about a woman who discovers that her grandmother had an affair with a Nawab in the 1920s.

Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, the author of Heat and Dust, is the only person to have won a Booker Prize and an Oscar, achieving the second for adapted screenplays of this author’s A Room with a View and Howards End.

Jhabvala was also nominated for an Oscar for a screenplay to a version of this novel set in 1956, much of whose narratives consist of reminisces about Lord Darlington and a conference he held just before World War 2.

bonuses.leadin: The original video to feature this phrase was tweeted by Josh Holz in 2016. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this two-word exclamation followed by “back at it again with the white Vans!” in a viral video.

The kids from the Damn Daniel video appear in the music video for this band’s song “California Kids,” which appears on the fourth of this band’s series of self-titled albums nicknamed for the color of their cover.
This Ghanaian-British singer featured Yung Baby Tate in her song “Damn Daniel.” Missy Elliott has a guest verse in this artist’s song “ATM,” in which she raps “push my button, my button again.”

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about influential political cartoons:
parts: This British magazine ran some of the most famous political cartoons, including Dropping the Pilot. The British Library contains an oval table where this magazine’s editors carved their names.
Perhaps the most famous political cartoon in American history is Join or Die, a cartoon by this man depicting the 13 Colonies as sections of a chopped-apart snake.

This political cartoonist’s scathing critiques of Richard Nixon, including a cartoon in which Nixon crawls out of a sewer to meet the press, apparently caused Nixon to cancel his subscription to The Washington Post.
